bibl.title: STATE OF NEBRASKA Sixth Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE Orthopedic Hospital To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium ending November 30, 1916

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Sixth Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent t)K THE Orthopedic Hospital LINCOLN, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium ending November 30. 1916

SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF OFFICERS Dm. H. Winnett Orh Superintendent Dr. J. P. Lord Chief Surgeon Carrie M. Ben brook „ Matron Louie M. Corse Head Nurse Zella Smith Surgical Nurse Grace M. Eddy Assistant Nurse Rose Deahn Stenographer

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ORTHOPEDIC HOSPITAL Lincoln, Nebraska To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morchead, Governor, and to the Honorable members of the Board of Commis - sioners of State Institutions, Howard Kennedy, Henry Gerdes and Silas A. Holcomb: Gentlemen: In compliance with the statutes, the sixth biennial report is, herewith, submitted. HISTORICAL The Orthopedic Hospital was created by an enactment of the Legislature of 1905. $10,000 was appropriated for the establishment of the institution and its maintenance for the first biennium. The hospital was provided for the care of the destitute crippled and deformed of Nebraska. A preliminary survey showed that a considerable number of Nebraska children were diseased and crippled and needed hospital care of a kind for which there were no facilities. The new hospital was located in a portion of one of the buildings of the Home for the Friendless in Lincoln. The summer of 1905 was spent in preparing the building for hospital work. The first patient was received on October 1, 1905. The following table indicates, in figures, the activ - ities of the hospital by biennial periods since that time.
SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF 336
,; ■< o I l' \] o Q H - O as o in r as fc'- O - *s ? r# Ct 1< J — ' i

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS In the second biennium additional space was provided by further remodelling for our use the entire building of which we had formerly occupied only a part. Further improvement and extension occurred also during the third biennium. About June 1, 1911, the entire group of buildings, (four in number), was taken over for the work of the hospital. In 1912, at an expense of about $6,000, a fireproof laundry building was erected. This building is giving good service. Substantial sleeping porches for nurses and employees were built. The Legislature of 1913 appropriated $45,000 for a new hospital building. This building was finished during the present biennium and will be referred to again. SCOPE OF THE WORK The hospital is designed primarily for the free treat - ment of children who are crippled or deformed or suffering from disease or defects likely to eventuate in deformity. Such conditions are infantile paralysis; tuberculosis of bones or joints, (hip joint disease, white swelling, hunch back, scrof - ula, etc. ) ; hare lip, club foot ; hernia ; fractures ; dislocations enlarged tonsils; adenoids; rickets, (bowlegs, knock knees etc.) The subjoined table indicates to how large an extent these are surgical patients. SURGICAL WORK DONE AT THE HOSPITAL DURING THE PAST TWO YEARS 3 Abscess, acute 2 Abscess, pulmonary Abscess cold, (see tuberculosis) 1 3 Adenitis, cervical Adenoids *21 1 Amputation, toe 1 imputation, painful stump 1 Ankylosis, congenital, knee 1 Ankylosis, acquired, knee

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 339 Paralysis, infantile, club foot, arthrdUesis 20 Paralysis, infantile, astragalectomy _ 7 Paralysis, infantile, forcible correction 38 Paralysis, infantile, tenoplasty 23 Paralysis, infantile, tenotomy 13 Paralysis, infantile, other contracture deformity 9 Paralysis, pseudo-hypertrophic _ 1 Paralysis, spastic, club foot Arthrodesis _ 1 Forcible correction 6 Tenoplasty 5 Paralysis, spastic, contracture deformity Paronychia X Phimosis 20 Pigeon-toe _ 1 Polyp rectum .-. „ 1 Pylorus stenosis 1 Sarcoma of eye _ : 1 Scapula, congenital elevation of 1 Spina bifida _ 1 Syphilis, acquired _ 1 Syphilis, hereditary 4 Teeth extracted 1 Tonsils 113 Tuberculosis: Hip < Knee 1 Spine I Uterus, prolapse of _ 1 580 The hospital care of these children is excellently supple- mented by our school work All patients from kindergarten to high school age have lessons and recite every day Our four teachers conduct classes in the school rooms and give individual instruction to bed patients in the wards The school operates the full twelve months of the year. The nurses' training school with 18 to 20 pupil nurses enrolled is an important feature of the work of the institu- tion. The State Library Commission has installed and super- vises a splendid institution library which is available to pa- tients and employees.

SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF Diversions are provided for the children in various ways. Occasional entertainments are given by visitors to the hos - pital and down town theaters are frequently thrown open to the children. The Oliver and Orpheum theaters and Capital Beach have been especially generous and Mr. J. M. Bramlette of the Lincoln Traction Company has frequently provided street car transportation for the children to and from down town entertainments. ACTIVITIES OF THE PAST TWO YEARS tThe institution has reached a stage of greater usefulness at any previous time. Under the administration of the d of Commissioners of State Institutions the hospital not only expanded to a 140-bed institution but its effici - has also been materially increased. I The new building was finished and has been occupied ce March 1, 1915. This building contains new and modern ce rooms, library, reception rooms, dining rooms, school ims, laboratory, surgical department complete, and three rds with a capacity of forty beds. The building is fire - >of and the different floors communicate by inclines instead stairways. During the past year one of the striking changes in our methods was that of converting our separate children's, nurses' and employees' dining rooms into a single cafeteria. This enables us to serve meals in a moderate sized dining room and the food is served more promptly and economically and in better condition than under the old system. In January, 1916, we were honored by having with us for several days Dr. E. W. Ryerson of Chicago, Dr. Emil Geist of Minneapolis, Dr. M. S. Henderson of Rochester and Dr. A. Steindler of Des Moines. With Dr. Lord and the sup - erintendent these gentlemen spent two days in a clinical and surgical study of methods in infantile paralysis. About twenty separate surgical procedures were done and a collec - tive report will be published in due time showing the methods used and the ultimate results obtained.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 341 This institution, in common with other Nebraska insti - tutions, has enjoyed and profited by the several conferences of officers of Nebraska institutions with the Board of Com - missioners of State Institutions. These conferences have twice been held at our hospital and we are very glad to have their influence and enthusiasm brought close to us in this way. About 50 '/r addition to our boiler room was made during the past year. This will enable us to heat the new adjoining building of the Nebraska Home for Dependent Children and will give us better service. Some painting has been done in the interior of our buildings. Minor building, plumbing, and electrical repairs have been made as required. RECOMMENDATIONS A sprinkler system for the old hospital building and old main building. Fire escapes for the new building and sun parlors of old building. Removal of the x-ray room to the new building and exten - sion of x-ray equipment. Employment of definite part time assistant physician and laboratory assistant and the addition of a night supervisor to our graduate nursing staff. To make provision for teachers and equipment for teach - ing at least three or four of the following: Carpenter shop work, watch making, shoe making and repairing, painting, and brace shop. A superintendent's residence. Extensive painting both inside and outside of all the buildings. Tear down the old laundry building and put cement plat - form over boiler and new coal bin Tile floor and side walls in kitchen and cold storage. Replacement of all wooden stairways with stairways of fireproof construction. Removal of the old pavillion.

342 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF New coal bin to the west of the boiler room. Fireproof roof on the old part of the main building. tTo make our maintenance appropriation for the next nium upon a basis of $1.40 per day for an average of 140 ;nts. CONCLUSION I The superintendent desires to extend his thanks espec - to Hon. Howard Kennedy, Hon. Silas A. Holcomb and . Henry Gerdes, the members of the Board of Commis - ers of State Institutions, who have exerted themselves ringly during the biennium in behalf of the Orthopedic pital and all of the other State institutions. The hospital specially indebted also to other State officers and to many r Nebraska and Lincoln citizens and to Miss Billie Burke to the Lincoln committee with Mrs. D. F. Easterday as rman, for generous gifts and attentions at Christmas other times. More children have been helped to physical and mental independence than during any previous biennial period. It is a great satisfaction for us to feel that now considerably more than 1000 children have been cured or greatly benefitted by the hospital and educational care they received at this institution. We respectfully bespeak for our children and our work the same liberal and enthusiastic support which has been accorded heretofore. Respectfully submitted, H. WlNNETT ORR, Superintendent. Lincoln, S'rbraska, S'ovenber SO, 1916.
